snippet: Corrections appearing in print on April 14, 2012.
The Hall of Fame trainer Bob Baffert will be home recovering from a heart attack when Bodemeister and Secret Circle, two Kentucky Derby hopefuls, run in the Arkansas Derby on Saturday.
abstract: Hall of Fame horse trainer Bob Baffert will be home recovering from a heart attack when his two Kentucky Derby hopefuls Bodemeister and Secret Circle run in the Arkansas Derby.

headline.main: For Baffert, Derby Victory Would Be Best Medicine
headline.print_headline: For Baffert, Victory May Be Best Remedy

snippet: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes items on Steve Jobs Avenue in Brazil, a promising new note-taking app and a strategy that is reported to have be...
abstract: The technology reporters and editors of The New York Times scour the Web for important and peculiar items. Friday's selection includes items on Steve Jobs Avenue in Brazil, a promising new note-taking app and a strategy that is reported to have been proposed at RIM before the chief left.

headline.main: Today's Scuttlebot: Digital Designers, and 3-D Chocolate Printers

snippet: Is Apple doing enough to protect parents' wallets from their own children? That seems to be the debate that has been brewing in a year-old lawsuit related to iPhone apps and the purchasing mechanisms inside them. After parents type in their passwo...
abstract: Is Apple doing enough to protect parents' wallets from their own children? That seems to be the debate that has been brewing in a year-old lawsuit related to iPhone apps and the purchasing mechanisms inside them. After parents type in their password to the App Store, children have a window to keep buying stuff.

headline.main: Parents' Fight With Apple Over 'Bait Apps' Moves Forward

snippet: Facebook has transformed how we keep tabs on friends, by training people. A site called Wavii opened to the public earlier this week that wants to do the same thing for topics.
abstract: Facebook has transformed how we keep tabs on friends, by training people. A site called Wavii opened to the public earlier this week that wants to do the same thing for topics.

snippet: Does the Obama campaign want the public to see Mitt Romney as the return of Don Draper (minus the drinking and womanizing)? Also, the Batman director worries that digital movie production has taken over, and details on Julian Assange's new talk sh...
abstract: Does the Obama campaign want the public to see Mitt Romney as the return of Don Draper (minus the drinking and womanizing)? Also, the Batman director worries that digital movie production has taken over, and details on Julian Assange's new talk show.

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Back to the '50s in Politics, and Chris Nolan on Shooting in Film

snippet: Today’s idealists are wonderful folk, but they could use a healthy dose of moral realism.
Gu Kailai, a lawyer, spent more than two decades turning the government posts of her husband, Bo Xilai, into lucrative business opportunities.
abstract: Scandal involving the death of British businessman Neil Heywood in China appears to be evolving into a broader investigation into the wealth and financial interests of politically powerful Chinese couple Bo Xilai and his wife Gu Kailai; analysts say Communist Party leaders, by moving decisively against Gu and Bo, are trying to send a message to allies of Bo, who are still putting up resistance.

headline.main: Murder Aside, China Inquiry Puts Couple’s Wealth on Trial
headline.print_headline: Murder Aside, China Inquiry Puts Couple’s Wealth on Trial

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS and MICHAEL WINES

snippet: Kazuo Hirai said he would focus Sony’s resources away from its unprofitable television business and more toward mobile devices, cameras and games.
abstract: Sony chief executive Kazuo Hirai details company's turnaround plan, saying focus will shift resources away from the unprofitable television business and toward mobile devices, cameras and games; plan also includes cutting 10,000 jobs; Sony has had four consecutive years of losses, but has rapidly lost ground to other companies.

headline.main: Sony Chief Unveils Plans to Revive Company
headline.print_headline: Sony’s New Chief Lays Out a Plan for a Turnaround

byline.original: By HIROKO TABUCHI and BETTINA WASSENER

snippet: A picture on Friday with the City Room column, about the 100th anniversary of a gift of cherry trees to New York City from Japan, was published in error. It showed crab apple trees, not cherry blossoms in Riverside Park north of 90th Street in Man...
